Description: Shoulder sherd of Milesian Fikellura pottery neck-amphora; white slip; exterior, from top: brown band on ridged junction of neck and shoulder; band of interlinked lotus buds and flowers with added purple on petals and kalyxes; dividing band of gear pattern between pairs of lines; painted decoration consisting of part of head to right of possible female dancer (eyes, mouth, nose, right ear, forehead and top of head with purple headwear remaining); at right, part of unidentified decoration (probably castanets) and perhaps part of headgear in purple of second figure.
Producer name: Attributed to: Painter of the running satyrs
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The numbers "11" and "34" are written in pencil on the interior surface of the sherd.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 111, no. 321.15, pl. XXXIV, no. 321.15)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 246, no. 1)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 143-5, no. NAU 111, pl. 24, fig. c)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 215, no. 46)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GF.040)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4653 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
